logy and health. The specific lecture topics and exercises w

name: BIO ENG 101
about:
This course teaches the fundamental principles underlying mo
dern sensing and control instrumentation used in biology and

s-on approach to measurement theory and practice by presenti
ng and analyzing example instruments currently used for biol
ogy and medical research, including EEG, ECG, pulsed oximete
rs, Complete Blood Count (CBC), etc.

name: BIO ENG 102
about:
This course introduces, develops and applies the methods of 
continuum mechanics to biomechanical phenomena abundant in b
iology and medicine. It is intended for upper level undergra
duate students who have been exposed to vectors, differentia
l equations, and undergraduate course(s) in physics and cert
ain aspects of modern biology.

name: MAT SCI 102
about:
Bonding in solids; classification of metals, semiconductors,
 and insulators; crystal systems; point, line, and planar de
fects in crystals; examples of crystallographic and defect a
nalysis in engineering materials; relationship to physical a
nd mechanical properties.

name: BIO ENG 103
about:

the chemistry and structure of biomolecules (proteins, membr
anes, DNA, and RNA) and their thermodynamic and kinetic feat
ures in the crowded cellular environment. Topics include ent
ropy, bioenergetics, free energy, chemical potential, reacti
on kinetics, enzyme kinetics, diffusion and transport, non-e
quilibrium systems, and their connections to the cellular en
vironment.

name: MAT SCI 103
about:

s and microstructural changes in the solid state. Atom diffu
sion in solids. Phase transformations through the nucleation
 and growth of new matrix or precipitate phases. Martensitic
 transformations, spinodal decomposition. The use of phase t
ransformations to control microstructure.

name: BIO ENG 104
about:

the function of living systems and the design of medical dev
ices. Biological transport phenomena are present at a wide r
ange of length scales: molecular, cellular, organ (whole and
 by functional unit), and organism. This course develops and
 applies scaling laws and the methods of continuum mechanics
 to biological transport phenomena over a range of length an
d time scales. The course

x-ray diffraction and electron microscopy techniques for cha
racterization of the chemical and structural properties of a

, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and transmission elect

cademic integrity. Students will get hands-on experience usi
ng the XRD, SEM and TEM equipment to perform microstructural
 characterization of materials. Students will also design an
d run their own project on a topic of their choosing.

sis, signal processing, and instrumentation development from

origin of biological signals and recording mechanisms; and d
esign considerations including sensitivity, accuracy, and ma
rket potential. This course is designed

about:

about:

n key attributes of embryonic stem cells (ESC), will introdu

about:

uantification, protein expression, gene expression, and cell

name: BIO ENG 116
about:
The goal of tissue engineering is to fabricate substitutes t
o restore tissue structure and functions. Understanding cell
 function in response to environmental cues will help us to 
establish design criteria and develop engineering tools for 
tissue fabrication. This course will introduce the basic con
cepts and approaches in the field, and train students to des

nets, ferrites and magneto-optic and -resistive materials. T

onse to structural implants are examined. Quantitative treat
ment of biomechanical issues and constitutive relationships 
of tissues are covered in order to design biomaterial replac

ials selection and design. Structure-property relationships

. Topics include introduction to different classes of nanoma
terials, synthesis and characterization of nanomaterials, an

about:

 and insulators; crystal systems; point, line, and planar de

ices. Biological transport phenomena are present at a wide r

 to biological transport phenomena over a range of length an

x-ray diffraction and electron microscopy techniques for cha

, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and transmission elect

cademic integrity. Students will get hands-on experience usi
ng the XRD, SEM and TEM equipment to perform microstructural

d run their own project on a topic of their choosing.

origin of biological signals and recording mechanisms; and d
esign considerations including sensitivity, accuracy, and ma
rket potential. This course is designed

establish design criteria and develop engineering tools for 
tissue fabrication. This course will introduce the basic con

ctric and magnetic properties of solids. Processing-microstr

ment of biomechanical issues and constitutive relationships

ropy, bioenergetics, free energy, chemical potential, reacti

 to biological transport phenomena over a range of length an
